<td colspan="2" align="left" valign="top"> <div align="left"> <table width="100%"  border="0">

Two panels in the 15th-century east window of the church of St Peter Mancroft, Norwich. The left-hand panel illustrates the Annunciation, the right- hand, the Visitation (for this panel, see Image 509 in the Visitation episode).

In the Annunciation panel, a crowned Mary kneels at a prayer-desk covered in a rich brocade, upon which lies an open book. In the foreground: the pot of lilies. To the right: a scroll inscribed 'Ecce ancilla domini'. At the extreme right: a blue curtain is drawn back to reveal a bed, with a red coverlet with black 'MR' monograms. Behind in the background, a landscape. The archangel Gabriel kneels, holding a sceptre over his left shoulder. His scroll is inscribed 'Ave

gr(atia) plena dominus tecu(m)'. Between these two figures descends, down golden rays of glory from a cloud, the nimbed dove of the Holy Spirit, followed by the Christ Child already carrying his cross. This is a rare survival of the motif of the child descending to Mary at the Annunciation - it came to be thought heretical, in implying that Christ was not formed in Mary's womb.
